description: From Yiddish כּשר‎ (kosher), from Hebrew כָּשֵׁר‎ (kashér).

adjectives.description: kosher (comparative more kosher, superlative most kosher)

entries.meaning: (Judaism) Fit for use or consumption, in accordance with Jewish law (especially relating to food).
examples: Only in New York can you find a good, kosher hamburger!
David's mother kept a kosher kitchen, with separate sets of dishes for meat and for dairy.
In order for a suit to be kosher, it cannot contain both wool and linen together.

entries.meaning: (figuratively, by extension) In accordance with standards or usual practice.
examples: Is what I have done kosher with Mr. Smith?

entries.meaning: In a kosher manner; in accordance with kashrut.

verbs.description: kosher (third-person singular simple present koshers, present participle koshering, simple past and past participle koshered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To kasher; to prepare (for example, meat) in conformity with the requirements of the Jewish law.
